EARLL MURMAN: So we left
the two hardest topics to the end of the course. People and I think
Annalisa, I want to congratulate her for doing
a great job on that module

in implementation.  So here's the kind
of thing you're going

to face on implementation. I've learned these three
things about new programs.

Never oppose them because
you'll get fired, never do any work on them,
and in three months

you'll never hear
about them again. I've been here for 23
years, I've seen 23 of these come and go, and that's for
an auto supplier supervisor.

So when you go to
implement this, you're going to find a lot of
cynicism, a lot of reluctance.

Not amongst everybody,
but there are going to be people who
actively kind of try to--
cave dweller. Cave dwellers, yeah.

AUDIENCE: Those are
called passive resistance. EARLL MURMAN: Yeah, you'll
be lucky if it's passive.

Now, one of the things is
I don't think Lean or Lean Six Sigma are ACE
or Textron Six Sigma

or Northrop Grumman,
whatever they call it, is going to go away. These things have now been
in there for 10 years.

It's not the flavor
of the month, these are fundamental
transformation that the industry
is going through.

And as Ida said, it's a journey
which is going to take years. And the reason we like
to teach this course

is because that's what you're
going to graduate into. And believe me, if you
come in with an open mind

to join that group,
your career advancement is going to be much greater. Here are our objectives.

So we want you to be
able to understand, be able to describe, what these
steps are for implementing

Lean principles and practices,
to list some of the barriers, and to apply some basic
tools for implementation

of a Lean improvement project. And for that, we're going
to use this Accounts Payable one as an example.

Ida already said this, I
don't have to put this up, two critical things you need
for implementation-- you

need the leadership
and the commitment. And these principles are
not complicated principles.

These are common-sense
principles. Dave Driscoll at Sikorsky,
one of the United Technologies companies, was taking me through
his plant a couple of years

ago. Actually, with one of my
classes I took down there. And he said, Earll,
my definition of Lean is the focused application
of common sense.

That's the easy part. The hard part is
making the change.

The challenge is
implementing and sustaining that transformation
and sustaining it through leadership changes,
through business changes,

and so on. And it's complex to
change the thinking of a large
organization, and there

is no one path through this. Each organization creates its
own path, its own journey,

depending on where it's
starting and where it goes. It's a puzzle.

It's a puzzle you
got to figure out. You're often lost
in the maze, you don't know where you
are in this journey.

You wish you were
making more progress, are you making progress? You got forks in the road,
and as Yogi Berra said,

when you find a fork
in the road, take it. And sometimes you don't know
what your directions are.

So what we're going to
try to do on this module is give you a little bit
of a framework for how you

would go about implementing. It's not a recipe,
but a framework. So let's just
think for a minute.

We've done our value
stream analysis for Accounts Payable
at Rockwell Collins.

Let's just use as
our baseline example. Where are we going to start?

What tools do we have
available to help us? How are we going to
measure progress?

about it, but what do you think the biggest
challenges are going

to be in implementing
a new Accounts Payable process at Rockwell Collins?

Not just your organization,

the Lean paradigm.

Lean learning through education and leadership.

the senior management buy in. What happens if the senior
management doesn't buy in?
What do you do? You find new senior management.

It's one of these things, either
you're on board or you're gone. You can't make a change like
this where you got resistance

stuck in political warfare. OK, we've already
seen this chart,

of the senior leader is to get that alignment of the
employees through some vision.

Iridium program earlier in the Lean engineering. They had a real vision. They wanted to do something
never been done before.

They wanted to provide
worldwide cell phone coverage. Unfortunately the business
model didn't work,

but the vision did. That really got
everybody aligned. That's what they
were going to do.

Then you want to focus
on the value stream. We don't have to
repeat that here.

We want to get that
vision internalized within the organization,
not just something we put on the wall on a
sticky paper or something,

but something where people
really know what that means. Get some goals and metrics.

We heard that-- was it
Louie [INAUDIBLE] you said? Or Steve Finger.

It was Steve Finger you said. We're going to be goal
organization by 2008. Well, maybe that's not, but
at least you got a goal.

And then think about who those
stakeholders are that are going to be involved in this. If you have an
important stakeholder

and they're not
inside the circle, you're going to at some
point reach a breakage
where you can't implement it.

So it's this top level. I just want to remind
you of this chart. We had this up, I
think, in the first day in Al's opening module.

Lean applies to every
enterprise process. It's not just manufacturing, and
I think you all know that now.

But I'll tell you, you
go in these companies and talk to the engineers
and they say, oh, no,

that's a manufacturing
thing, doesn't apply to me. And that's changing
with time but, you're

e to find that in other areas,
too, where people say, well, that's manufacturing,
doesn't apply to me,

but these are all changing. But you can't do
everything at once. You don't have enough resources
to tackle everything at once,

so you've got to
pick some targets. Then we got to get the behavior,
the kind of thing Annalisa

was talking about. We got to organize for
this Lean implementation and develop the behavior in
the organization and the people

that are going to be
aligned with that. Now, you can't do that between
Friday night and Monday morning.

You're talking about
a few years here to get the behavior aligned. And the reason we're
teaching you guys

this course is
because you're going to go out in that environment. If you walk in
with that behavior,

if you walk in with
an mind and say, this is something I'm
going to benefit from it

and I can contribute to,
you've taken two or three years off the startup of your career.

Then we got to get
some change agents, people that are going
to work with you to--

I mean, people who are
passionate about that. The Chris Cools, who was
up on the Annalisa slides,

Ida [INAUDIBLE]. I mean, they're change
agents in the organizations. The George Reynolds. You got to have some incentives
that align with that.

You can't say, this is
what I want you to do, and then at the end of
the year, you give them a raise for something else. Guess what?

They're going to get that
message pretty quickly. And you have your
structure and your systems,

some of the reporting
systems, and so on, that have to align with that. So here we've kind of gathered
together just some comparisons

for you between
what you might think of as an organization that
has a mass mentality and one

that has a Lean mentality. And boy, we walked into
New Balance on Wednesday

and they didn't say, this
is our cutting department and this is our boxing
department, and so on.

This is our value stream. They said, we have five
value streams in this plant.

I couldn't believe it. I mean, they're organized
by value stream.

Instead of having these
departments where people work on the department
job and pass it as [INAUDIBLE] over the
wall, over the brick wall,

you got multifunctional teams
that are working together at the start. Instead of having everybody
have their own specialized job

categories, you got
few job categories. This has been a huge change
for some of the unions.

One of the big
things I remember, one of our early LAI
partners-- unfortunately,

they didn't stay with us--
was a plant down in Texas, Ling-Temco-Vought, who
now is having such supply

problems with the 787,
but they'll get past that. And they'd negotiated with the
UAW, the United Auto Workers,

to greatly reduce the number
of different job categories so that they could
be more productive. It was a win-win situation.

Instead of having a
structure as Annalisa showed on the matrix
vertical structure,

you want to have a
horizontal structure-- people making decisions
at the level they're at. Bosses who help facilitate
rather than direct.

Instead of communication
going up and down, it's just gets
everywhere quickly.

Southwest Airlines is that
way, as Annalisa said. Rapid, timely,
frequent communication.

Everybody in the departure
process of Southwest Airlines knows what's going on. If you read that
book, you find out

that they really emphasize that
the operations, whether they call it dispatch or whatever
it is, somebody who's

kind of orchestrating all
these different airplanes leaving and arriving and so
on, they just keep everybody

informed what's happening. Focus on the customer,
not the product,

we've talked about that. Suppliers, we've
talked about that. The flexible,
agile organization.

So these are fundamental
changes in an organization, and these changes take
years to really implement.

OK, the enterprise leader plays
a really critical role here. Basically they lead
rather than direct.

There's a difference between
leading and directing. And let's just move
on because I think

Annalisa had that up there
on the leadership charts. But why do they do that?

Because the knowledge exists
in the frontline workers. And that's, by the way, why
engineers should embrace Lean.

Engineers are right
in the value stream. They're not on the side
of the value stream, they're right in
the value stream.

So engineers,
production workers, are the winners in
a Lean organization, and that's why it's
so important we

try to get that message across. Now, there are a

going to get mixed signals Oh, OK, well that's

the really critical things,

upfront that nobody's going
to lose their job because of Lean implementation. They may lose their job
because the business goes down

or they may lose their job

lose their job because they increase productivity.

And any organization
that doesn't implement Lean that way is going to fail.

And believe me,
